arithmetic.title: Arithmetic
arithmetic.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in arithmetic

cards.name: Sum of the first $n$ natural numbers
vars: n is a positive integer.
cards.desc: Gives the sum of all natural numbers from \(1\) up to \(n\). Often illustrated by pairing terms (e.g. \(1+n\), \(2+(n-1)\), etc.) to simplify the addition.

cards.name: Arithmetic sequence (nth term)
vars: a_n is the nth term of the sequence, a_1 is the first term, d is the common difference, and n is the term index.
cards.desc: Defines the general term of an arithmetic progression (constant difference between consecutive terms). A linear graph represents the sequence values.

cards.name: Arithmetic series (sum of first $n$ terms of an AP)
vars: S_n is the sum of the first n terms, a_1 is the first term, d is the common difference, n is the number of terms.
cards.desc: Calculates the sum of an arithmetic progression. Often visualized by pairing terms from ends toward the center (which all yield the same sum).

number_theory.title: Number Theory
number_theory.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in number theory

cards.name: Fermat's Little Theorem
vars: p is a prime number, a is an integer not divisible by p.
cards.desc: In modular arithmetic, this theorem states that if \(p\) is prime, then \(a^{p-1}\) leaves a remainder of \(1\) upon division by \(p\). It’s fundamental for simplifying exponents mod \(p\).

cards.name: Euler's Totient (Phi) Formula
vars: n is a positive integer, and the product is over each prime p dividing n.

algebra.title: Algebra
algebra.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in algebra

cards.name: Quadratic Formula
cards.desc: Gives the solutions for a quadratic equation of any form. It is typically illustrated by the parabola of \(y = ax^2+bx+c\) intersecting the \(x\)-axis at \(x\) values given by this formula (the roots).

cards.name: Binomial Theorem
cards.desc: Expands a binomial raised to an integer power into a sum of terms. Often visualized using Pascal’s Triangle for binomial coefficients.

cards.name: Common Factoring Identity (Difference of Squares)
vars: a and b are any expressions or numbers.
cards.desc: Fundamental algebraic identity used to factor the difference between two squares. It’s often demonstrated graphically by the difference in areas of squares of side \(a\) and side \(b\).

cards.name: Combination Formula
cards.desc: Computes the number of ways to choose \(k\) items from \(n\) without order. This formula is central in combinatorics and appears in binomial expansions and probability calculations.

geometry.title: Geometry (Euclidean)
geometry.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in geometry (euclidean)

cards.name: Pythagorean Theorem
vars: a and b are the lengths of the legs (perpendicular sides) of a right triangle, and c is the length of the hypotenuse (side opposite the right angle).
cards.desc: Relates the side lengths of a right-angled triangle. It is used to find the third side given the other two.

cards.name: Sum of Interior Angles (Polygon)
vars: n is the number of sides of a polygon.

cards.name: Volume of a Rectangular Prism (Cuboid)
vars: L, W, H are the length, width, and height of the rectangular solid (for a cube, all three are equal to a).
cards.desc: Computes the volume (space inside) of a box-shaped object. Visualized as counting unit cubes that fill a rectangular box.

cards.name: Volume of a Cylinder
vars: r is the base radius, h is the height of the cylinder.

cards.name: Volume of a Cone/Pyramid
cards.desc: The volume of any pyramid (base with triangular sides meeting at a point) is one-third the base area times height. Visual proof involves stacking three congruent pyramids to fill a prism.

cards.name: Volume of a Sphere
vars: r is the radius of the sphere.
cards.desc: Gives the volume inside a sphere (ball).

trigonometry.title: Trigonometry
trigonometry.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in trigonometry

cards.name: Trigonometric Ratios (right triangle definitions)
cards.desc: Defines sine, cosine, and tangent as ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle.

cards.name: Law of Sines (for any triangle)
vars: A, B, C are the angles of a triangle, and a, b, c are the side lengths opposite those angles, respectively.
cards.desc: Relates the ratios of each side length to the sine of its opposite angle; useful for solving general (non-right) triangles. Usually accompanied by a triangle diagram showing angles and opposite sides.

cards.name: Law of Cosines
vars: a, b, c are side lengths of a triangle, and C is the angle opposite side c.
cards.desc: Generalizes the Pythagorean theorem to any triangle. It finds a third side or an angle, useful when the Law of Sines is ambiguous or not applicable. Visualized by dropping perpendiculars in a non-right triangle to derive the relation.

analytic_geometry.title: Analytic Geometry
analytic_geometry.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in analytic geometry

cards.name: Distance Between Two Points (2D)
vars: (x_1, y_1) and (x_2, y_2) are the coordinates of the two points.
cards.desc: Calculates the straight-line distance between two points in the plane, derived from the Pythagorean theorem.

cards.name: Midpoint of Two Points
vars: (x_1, y_1) and (x_2, y_2) are the coordinates of the endpoints of a line segment; M is the midpoint coordinates.
cards.desc: Gives the coordinate of the point exactly in the middle of two given points.

cards.name: Slope of a Line
vars: (x_1, y_1) and (x_2, y_2) are two distinct points on a line; m is the slope.
cards.desc: Measures the steepness or inclination of a line as the ratio of vertical change to horizontal change.

cards.name: Equation of a Line (Slope-Intercept Form)
vars: m is the slope of the line, b is the y-intercept (the y value when x=0), x,y are the coordinates of any point on the line.
cards.desc: Represents a line in the plane with slope \(m\) and intercept \(b\). The graph is a straight line crossing the \(y\)-axis at \((0,b)\).

cards.name: Circle (Standard Equation)
vars: (h, k) is the center of the circle, r is the radius, (x, y) is any point on the circle.
cards.desc: Describes all points that are a fixed distance \(r\) from a center \((h,k)\).

cards.name: Ellipse (Standard Form)
vars: (h,k) is the center of the ellipse, a is the semi-major radius (horizontal if a>b), b is the semi-minor radius (vertical if a>b).
cards.desc: Represents an ellipse – the set of points for which the sum of distances to two foci is constant. If \(a = b\), this reduces to a circle.

cards.name: Equation of a Plane (3D)
vars: A, B, C, D are constants defining the plane; (x,y,z) is any point on the plane. (The vector (A,B,C) is normal perpendicular to the plane.)
cards.desc: General form of a plane in three-dimensional space. Any point satisfying this linear equation lies on the plane.

differential_geometry.title: Differential Geometry
differential_geometry.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in differential geometry

cards.name: Arc Length of a Curve
vars: y'(x) is the derivative (slope) of the curve y(x); the integral is evaluated from x=a to x=b, the x-coordinates of the endpoints of the curve segment.

calculus.title: Calculus
calculus.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in calculus

cards.name: Definition of Derivative
vars: f(x) is a function, f'(x) is its derivative. h is an increment in x (approaching 0 in the limit).
cards.desc: Defines the derivative as the instantaneous rate of change or slope of the function \(f(x)\) at point \(x\). Graphically, it’s the slope of the tangent line to \(y=f(x)\) at \(x\).

cards.name: Power Rule (for derivatives)
vars: n is a constant exponent, x is the variable.
cards.desc: Provides a quick way to differentiate monomials. For example, if \(f(x)=x^5\), then \(f'(x)=5x^4\). This rule is fundamental for polynomial differentiation.

cards.name: Indefinite Integral (Power Rule)
vars: n is a constant exponent (not -1); C is the constant of integration (since antiderivatives are determined up to an additive constant).

cards.name: Integration by Parts
vars: u and v are functions of x such that du and dv are their differentials (derivatives times dx). Often one sets u=f(x) and dv = g(x)dx.

vector_calculus.title: Vector Calculus
vector_calculus.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in vector calculus

cards.name: Gradient (of a scalar field)
cards.tex: \displaystyle \nabla f = \Big(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial z}\Big)

cards.name: Divergence (of a vector field)
cards.tex: \displaystyle \nabla\cdot \mathbf{F} = \frac{\partial P}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial Q}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial R}{\partial z}
cards.desc: Divergence is a scalar field representing the net rate of "outflow" from an infinitesimal volume at each point. Positive divergence indicates a source (flow expanding outward), negative indicates a sink.

cards.name: Curl (of a vector field)
cards.tex: \displaystyle \nabla \times \mathbf{F} = \Big(\frac{\partial R}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial Q}{\partial z}, \frac{\partial P}{\partial z} - \frac{\partial R}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y}\Big)

cards.name: Laplacian
cards.tex: \displaystyle \nabla^2 f = \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x^2} + \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2} + \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial z^2}
vars: f is a twice-differentiable scalar function of x,y,z.

cards.name: Green’s Theorem (in the plane)
cards.tex: \displaystyle \iint_{D}\Big(\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y}\Big)\,dA = \oint_{\partial D} \big(P\,dx + Q\,dy\big)
cards.desc: Relates a double integral over region \(D\) to a line integral around its boundary. It’s a special case of Stokes’ Theorem in 2D, often used to convert between circulation (line integral) and curl (area integral).

cards.name: Divergence Theorem (Gauss’s Theorem)
cards.desc: Relates the flux of a vector field out of a closed surface to the volume integral of the divergence over the region inside. In essence, it formalizes that the total "outflow" from a volume equals the sum of all sources inside.

linear_algebra.title: Linear Algebra
linear_algebra.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in linear algebra

cards.name: Dot Product
cards.tex: \mathbf{u}\cdot \mathbf{v} = u_x v_x + u_y v_y + u_z v_z = |\mathbf{u}|\;|\mathbf{v}|\cos\theta
cards.desc: Produces a scalar equal to the sum of component-wise products. It measures how much one vector extends in the direction of another. If the dot product is zero, vectors are perpendicular (orthogonal).

cards.name: Cross Product (3D vectors)
cards.tex: \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{v} = (u_y v_z - u_z v_y,\; u_z v_x - u_x v_z,\; u_x v_y - u_y v_x)

abstract_algebra.title: Abstract Algebra
abstract_algebra.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in abstract algebra

cards.name: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
cards.desc: Relates the size of an orbit of an element to the size of its stabilizer and the whole group. It’s a foundational result in group actions, often used to count objects via Burnside’s lemma. Think of splitting the group's action into independent moves on \(x\) (orbit size) and those that do nothing to \(x\) (stabilizer).

probability.title: Probability
probability.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in probability

cards.name: Probability (classical definition)
cards.tex: P(A) = \dfrac{\text{number of favorable outcomes}}{\text{number of possible outcomes}}
vars: A is an event in a finite sample space with equally likely outcomes.
cards.desc: Gives the probability of event \(A\) by ratio if all outcomes are equally likely. For example, the probability of rolling a 5 on a fair six-sided die is \(1/6\).

cards.name: Complement Rule
cards.desc: The probability that \(A\)

cards.name: Addition Rule (Union of Events)
cards.tex: P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)

cards.name: Conditional Probability
cards.desc: Updates the probability of \(A\) under the condition that \(B\) is known to have happened. For example, the probability it’s raining given that the sky is cloudy. Visually explained using a restricted sample space (just \(B\) outcomes).

cards.name: Bayes’ Theorem
cards.desc: Allows inversion of conditional probabilities. It’s fundamental in statistical inference, relating the probability of a cause \(A\) given effect \(B\) to the probability of effect given cause. Often visualized with probability trees or Bayes’ boxes.

cards.name: Binomial Distribution (Probability of $k$ successes)
cards.desc: Gives the probability of exactly \(k\) successes in \(n\) Bernoulli trials. For example, the chance of getting exactly 3 heads in 5 fair coin flips. The distribution’s probabilities can be visualized with a histogram or Pascal’s triangle (for small \(n\)).

cards.name: Expected Value (Mean) of a Discrete Random Variable
vars: X is a random variable that takes values x_i with probability P(X=x_i).

statistics.title: Statistics
statistics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in statistics

cards.name: Arithmetic Mean (Average)
cards.desc: Gives the central tendency of a data set as the sum of values divided by count. It’s the balance point of the data distribution.

cards.name: z-Score (Standard Score)
cards.desc: Converts a value to standard units indicating how many standard deviations \(x\) is above (\(z>0\)) or below (\(z<0\)) the mean. It’s used to compare different distributions or to look up probabilities from standard normal tables.

logic.title: Logic
logic.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in logic

cards.name: Number of Truth Assignments
vars: n is the number of distinct boolean variables/propositions.
cards.desc: If you have \(n\) independent true/false propositions, there are \(2^n\) possible combinations of truth values. For example, 3 binary variables can have \(2^3 = 8\) configurations (as seen in a truth table with 8 rows).

set_theory.title: Set Theory
set_theory.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in set theory

cards.name: Union-Intersection (Inclusion-Exclusion for two sets)
vars: A and B are sets; |X| denotes the number of elements in set X.
cards.desc: Calculates the size of the union of two sets by adding their sizes and subtracting the overlap (which was counted twice). This principle generalizes to more sets with alternating plus and minus of intersections (inclusion-exclusion principle).

cards.name: Size of Power Set
cards.desc: The number of possible subsets of a set \(A\) is \(2^{|A|}\) (each element either in or out of a subset). For instance, a set with 3 elements has \(2^3=8\) subsets.

topology.title: Topology
topology.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in topology

cards.name: Euler’s Formula for Polyhedra
vars: V is the number of vertices, E the number of edges, F the number of faces of a convex polyhedron (or planar connected graph).
cards.desc: A classic result relating the counts of fundamental elements of polyhedra (e.g., a cube has \(V=8, E=12, F=6\), and indeed \(8-12+6=2\)). This is often shown by deforming the polyhedron to a network on a sphere or plane. It generalizes to \(V-E+F=2-2g\) for surfaces of higher genus \(g\).

differential_equations.title: Differential Equations
differential_equations.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in differential equations

cards.name: Exponential Growth/Decay
vars: y(t) is the quantity as a function of time t, k is the growth (k>0) or decay (k<0) rate constant, C is the initial amount y(0).
cards.desc: The differential equation states that the rate of change of \(y\) is proportional to its current amount. The solution is an exponential law. Examples: radioactive decay (negative \(k\)), population growth (positive \(k\)). The graph is an exponential curve increasing or decreasing over time.

cards.name: Simple Harmonic Motion (solution)
cards.tex: x'' + \omega^2 x = 0 \quad\implies\quad x(t) = A \cos(\omega t) + B \sin(\omega t)

index.title: Mathematics
index.lead: Comprehensive math reference with formulas and explanations

cards.name: Sum of the first $n$ natural numbers
vars: n is a positive integer.
cards.desc: Gives the sum of all natural numbers from \(1\) up to \(n\). Often illustrated by pairing terms (e.g. \(1+n\), \(2+(n-1)\), etc.) to simplify the addition.

cards.name: Fermat's Little Theorem
vars: p is a prime number, a is an integer not divisible by p.
cards.desc: In modular arithmetic, this theorem states that if \(p\) is prime, then \(a^{p-1}\) leaves a remainder of \(1\) upon division by \(p\). It’s fundamental for simplifying exponents mod \(p\).

cards.name: Quadratic Formula
cards.desc: Gives the solutions for a quadratic equation of any form. It is typically illustrated by the parabola of \(y = ax^2+bx+c\) intersecting the \(x\)-axis at \(x\) values given by this formula (the roots).

cards.name: Pythagorean Theorem
vars: a and b are the lengths of the legs (perpendicular sides) of a right triangle, and c is the length of the hypotenuse (side opposite the right angle).
cards.desc: Relates the side lengths of a right-angled triangle. It is used to find the third side given the other two.

cards.name: Trigonometric Ratios (right triangle definitions)
cards.desc: Defines sine, cosine, and tangent as ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle.

cards.name: Distance Between Two Points (2D)
vars: (x_1, y_1) and (x_2, y_2) are the coordinates of the two points.
cards.desc: Calculates the straight-line distance between two points in the plane, derived from the Pythagorean theorem.

mechanics.title: Mechanics
mechanics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in mechanics

cards.name: Newton’s Second Law
cards.desc: Fundamental law relating force, mass, and acceleration. It implies acceleration is proportional to net force and inversely proportional to mass.

cards.name: Weight (Force due to Gravity)
cards.desc: Weight is the gravitational force exerted on a mass by Earth (or another celestial body). It differs from mass; mass is constant, weight depends on local \(g\).

cards.name: Impulse
cards.desc: Momentum is the quantity of motion (mass times velocity). Impulse is the effect of a force acting over time, equal to the change in momentum. These are illustrated by collisions: e.g., a longer impact time reduces force for the same momentum change (crumple zones in cars).

cards.name: Power
cards.desc: Power is the rate of energy transfer or work done per second (measured in Watts). For example, 1 watt = 1 joule/second. The \(Fv\) form is useful for constant forces (e.g., power required to lift an object at constant speed). Often visualized with mechanical engines or electrical power calculations.

cards.name: Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation
cards.desc: Every mass exerts an attractive force on every other mass. This inverse-square law explains planetary orbits, moon’s gravity, etc.

cards.name: Gravitational Potential Energy (two masses)
vars: Same m_1, m_2, r, G as above. The negative sign indicates that the potential energy is zero at infinite separation and becomes more negative as masses come closer (bound state).
cards.desc: Energy associated with two masses in a gravitational field. As \(r\) decreases, \(U\) decreases (becomes more negative), meaning work would be required to separate them. Often visualized as a well or curve approaching 0 at infinity and dipping down as \(r\) decreases.

cards.name: Moment of Inertia (for discrete masses)
vars: m_i are point masses in the object, r_i is each mass’s distance to the axis of rotation. I depends on the axis chosen.
cards.desc: Moment of inertia is rotational inertia, representing how mass is distributed relative to the axis. It appears in rotational dynamics (\(I\) plays the role of \(m\)). For example, a solid disk vs. a hoop of equal mass have different \(I\) about the center (hoop has more mass at perimeter, larger \(I\)).

cards.name: Rotational Dynamics
cards.desc: This is the rotational analogue of \(F=ma\). It states that net torque produces angular acceleration proportional to the moment of inertia. For example, it requires more torque to spin up a heavier or more extended object at the same rate.

thermodynamics.title: Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in thermodynamics

cards.name: Ideal Gas Law
cards.desc: Equation of state for an ideal gas (point particles, no intermolecular forces). It combines Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, etc. Tells, for example, how pressure increases with temperature if volume is fixed.

electromagnetism.title: Electromagnetism
electromagnetism.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in electromagnetism

cards.name: Coulomb’s Law
cards.desc: Gives the electrostatic force between two charges. The force is attractive if charges are opposite, repulsive if like-signed. It is an inverse-square law similar in form to gravity.

cards.name: Electric Field of Point Charge
vars: q = source charge, r = distance from the charge, E = electric field magnitude at that distance (radially outward for q>0, inward for q<0).
cards.desc: The electric field is force per unit charge. For a point charge, it diminishes with distance squared.

cards.name: Electric Potential (Point Charge)
vars: q = point charge, r = distance from the charge, V = electric potential (voltage) at that point relative to infinity.
cards.desc: The electric potential is the potential energy per unit charge. For a point charge, it falls off as \(1/r\). Differences in \(V\) between two points give the work per charge to move between those points.

cards.name: Capacitance (Parallel Plate)
cards.desc: Capacitance is the ability to store charge per unit voltage (\(C=Q/V\)). For parallel plates, larger area or smaller gap yields bigger \(C\). This formula is a basic design equation for capacitors.

cards.name: Ohm’s Law
vars: V = voltage (potential difference across a resistor or circuit element), I = current through it, R = resistance.

cards.name: Electrical Power
vars: P = power (rate of electrical energy consumption or production), V = voltage across a component, I = current through it, R = resistance (if using that form).
cards.desc: Different forms of the power formula useful depending on known quantities. For instance, a 60 W light bulb on household 120 V draws \(I = P/V = 0.5\) A. The formulas also explain joule heating: \(I^2R\) is heat dissipated in a resistor.

cards.name: Speed of Light from EM Constants

optics.title: Optics
optics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in optics

cards.name: Thin Lens/Mirror Equation
vars: f = focal length of a lens or mirror, d_o = object distance (distance from object to lens/mirror), d_i = image distance (distance from lens/mirror to the image formed). (Sign conventions apply for virtual images, etc.)
cards.desc: Relates object distance, image distance, and focal length for paraxial rays. It works for converging lenses/mirrors (positive \(f\)) and diverging (using sign conventions with negative \(f\)). Often used with magnification formula for locating images.

cards.name: Magnification
vars: h_o = object height, h_i = image height, d_o = object distance, d_i = image distance. The negative sign indicates that a positive m (image upright) comes with a negative d_i in sign convention (virtual image for lenses, etc.), and a negative m means the image is inverted.
cards.desc: The magnification \(m\) tells how large the image is relative to the object and whether it’s inverted (negative \(m\)) or upright (positive \(m\)). For example, \(|m|=2\) means the image is twice as tall as the object.

cards.name: Lensmaker’s Formula
vars: f = focal length of a thin lens in air, n = refractive index of lens material, R_1 and R_2 = radii of curvature of the two lens surfaces (convention: R_1 is radius of surface facing the object, positive if center of curvature is on opposite side of incoming light).
cards.desc: Determines \(f\) from lens shape and material. For example, a symmetric bi-convex lens (\(R_1 = R_2 = R\)) in air has \(1/f = 2(n-1)/R\). It explains how stronger curvature (smaller \(R\)) or higher \(n\) gives a shorter focal length (more powerful lens).

waves-and-oscillations.title: Waves and Oscillations
waves-and-oscillations.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in waves and oscillations

cards.name: Period and Frequency
vars: T = period (time for one complete cycle), f = frequency.
cards.desc: Simply the reciprocal relationship between how long one cycle takes and how many cycles occur per second. If a pendulum swings back and forth in 2 seconds (\(T=2\) s), its frequency is \(0.5\) Hz.

cards.name: Pendulum (small angle) Period
vars: L = length of a simple pendulum (mass on a string), g = acceleration due to gravity. (This formula assumes small oscillation amplitude so that motion is approximately simple harmonic.)
cards.desc: Gives the time for one complete swing back-and-forth of a pendulum (for small angles). It shows period is independent of mass and amplitude (for small angles) and increases with the square root of length.

cards.name: Mass-Spring Oscillator Period
vars: m = mass attached to spring, k = spring force constant (stiffness).
cards.desc: The period of an object of mass \(m\) oscillating on a spring (assuming no damping). A stiffer spring (\(k\) large) gives a shorter period (faster oscillation), while a heavier mass gives a longer period.

cards.name: Wave Equation (one dimension)
vars: y(x,t) describes the wave displacement as function of position x and time t. v = wave speed (assumed constant here).
cards.desc: A differential equation that \(y(x,t)\) satisfies for many physical waves (on a string, sound, light in 1D). It states that the acceleration of a small segment (left side) is proportional to the curvature of the wave shape (right side) with factor \(v^2\). Solutions are typically \(y(x,t)=f(x-vt)+g(x+vt)\) (waves traveling right and left).

cards.name: Sound Intensity Level (Decibels)
cards.desc: Converts a wide range of sound intensity into a logarithmic scale that correlates with perceived loudness. An increase of 10 dB means intensity is 10 times higher (approx. twice as loud to the human ear).

quantum-mechanics.title: Quantum Mechanics
quantum-mechanics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in quantum mechanics

cards.name: Planck-Einstein Relation
cards.desc: Indicates that electromagnetic radiation is quantized into photons, each with energy proportional to frequency. Higher frequency (e.g., X-rays) means higher energy per photon than lower frequency (e.g., radio waves).

cards.name: Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle
cards.desc: There’s a fundamental limit to how precisely we can simultaneously know certain pairs of observables (like position and momentum). This is not due to measurement flaws, but inherent to quantum systems.

relativity.title: Relativity
relativity.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in relativity

cards.name: Length Contraction
cards.desc: Objects are measured to be shorter along the direction of motion relative to an observer for whom they are moving. For instance, a fast-moving rod or spaceship appears foreshortened. Like time dilation, this effect is only significant at speeds close to \(c\).

cards.name: Mass–Energy Equivalence
cards.desc: Shows mass is a concentrated form of energy. A small amount of mass can convert to a huge amount of energy (because \(c^2\) is large). This underlies nuclear reactions where binding energy differences (mass defects) release energy.

cards.name: Schwarzschild Radius (Black Hole)
vars: M = mass of a (spherically symmetric, non-rotating) object, G = gravitational constant, c = speed of light, r_s = Schwarzschild radius.
cards.desc: If an object of mass \(M\) is compressed within this radius, its escape velocity exceeds \(c\) and it becomes a black hole. For example, the Earth’s \(r_s\) is ~9 mm, the Sun’s ~3 km. This formula comes from General Relativity’s solution for spacetime around a mass.

cards.name: Gravitational Time Dilation (weak field)
vars: t_p is proper time (time measured by a clock at radius r in gravitational field), t_f is time measured by a far-away observer, M is mass of gravitating body, r is radial position of the clock (from center of mass).
cards.desc: Clocks deeper in a gravitational well (closer to a mass) run slower relative to clocks far away. This is a prediction of GR (even the GPS satellites must correct for this and special relativistic effects to synchronize with Earth clocks). When \(r\) is very large (far away), the factor tends to 1 (no dilation).

fluid-mechanics.title: Fluid Mechanics
fluid-mechanics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in fluid mechanics

cards.name: Hydrostatic Pressure
cards.desc: Pressure in a static fluid increases linearly with depth. This is why deep water has higher pressure. For example, every 10 m of water adds about 1 atmosphere of pressure.

cards.name: Buoyant Force (Archimedes’ Principle)
cards.desc: Any object in a fluid experiences an upward force equal to the weight of fluid it displaces. This principle explains floating: if \(F_b\) equals the object’s weight, it floats (weight of displaced fluid = weight of object).

cards.name: Equation of Continuity
vars: A_1, A_2 are cross-sectional areas of a flow tube at two locations, v_1, v_2 are fluid speeds at those locations (for an incompressible fluid).
cards.desc: Expresses mass conservation in steady flow: the volume flow rate \(A v\) is constant along a streamline. If a pipe narrows (smaller \(A\)), the fluid speed \(v\) increases.

nuclear-physics.lead: Essential formulas and concepts in nuclear physics
